newsitem.title: PAKISTAN: Plane drops fuel tanks over Karachi, 5 die.
newsitem.headline: Plane drops fuel tanks over Karachi, 5 die.

text.p: A Pakistan Air Force plane dumped its fuel tanks over a residential area in Karachi on Thursday, setting off a fire that killed at least five people and injured eight, police said.

The pilot of the Mirage fighter jet had to jettison the tanks after the aircraft developed engine trouble on a routine training flight early on Thursday, an official from the joint public relations department of the Pakistan Army, Air Force and Navy said.
"There was an engine fault in the plane and the pilot was forced to eject the fuel tanks to make a safe landing," the official said.
Witnesses said fire broke out when one of the fuel tanks fell on Gharibabad, a heavily populated residential area in Karachi's District Central.
Police said five people, including one child, died in the blaze. A police official earlier said four children died.
A spokesman for the Sattar Edhi Ambulance Services said at least 10 people were killed.
"There was a loud explosion...I thought a bomb had exploded," said teenager Rashid, who lives nearby.
"When I came out I saw neighbouring houses in a blaze."
Deputy Superintendent of Police Khawja Nisar said only one of the tanks from the fighter exploded.
"One fuel tank which fell in Gharibabad area exploded, the other one which fell in nearby Sharifabad locality did not explode and resulted only in minor injuries," he said
"We were lucky that the incident occurred early in the morning. Casualties could have been much higher if shops were open and there had been traffic on the road."
Witnesses said a female school teacher and teenage boy who were standing on the road were critically injured in the blaze.
"I saw them burning in front my eyes but could do nothing," said Rashid.
Ajmal, another witness, said: "I was standing outside when the accident had occurred. First the plane flew past and then we heard explosion. I thought the plane had fired rockets."
The plane landed safely at an air force base in Karachi.
